{"stories":{"featured":[{"story_id":185097,"story_date":1752067647,"slug":"molly-joyce-state-change-review","description":"Molly Joyce's latest is a seven-part electronic suite that transmutes clinical anatomy into abstract poetry.","full_text":"“No pulses/ No function/ No flexor/ No extensor/ No movement.” This is how Molly Joyce’s hospital files describe the injury to her left arm that has guided her work as a musician and composer. When she was only seven years old, Joyce was in a car accident that nearly amputated her hand. After a series of intensive surgeries, it was reattached and some mobility regained, but her acquired disability prevents her from playing traditional instruments. Her debut album, 2020’s Breaking and Entering, centered around the Magnus electric toy organ, which she felt was perfectly suited to her abilities. Her follow-up, 2022’s Perspective, was crafted from interviews with people with disabilities on topics like access, control, and resilience. With “State Change”, Joyce revisits the traumatic event itself through a narrative of the operations that she underwent as a child.

The album is structured as a seven-part suite that follows Joyce’s medical journey, from “August 6, 1999,” the date of the accident, to “July 27, 2007,” the final surgery. Joyce’s lyrics draw extensively from her surgeons’ reports, which are sometimes disturbing in their detail. However, she delivers them with such ethereality that the medical terminology is stripped of its morbidness; descriptions of tendons, nerves, and muscles are transmuted from clinical anatomy into abstract poetry. Despite the lightness of her vocals, the songs have real emotional weight. Joyce’s fears are never far from the surface, as she reminds us of her own perspective in the first track: “I am a girl/ In an accident/ I am a girl/ With an arm hanging by skin.” On “August 13 + 16, 1999,” which describes a setback in which a skin graft had to be undone, her frustration spills over through harrowing screams provided by Fire-Toolz.

The concept and form of “State Change” are perfectly joined through Joyce’s use of new electronic instruments that she can operate with her left hand. For example, “July 27, 2007” features notes and samples triggered with a KAiKU Music Glove, a wearable MIDI controller. On “April 19, 2000,” sawtooth waves are modulated with a MUGIC (Music/User Gesture Interface Control) device through the vertical twisting of Joyce’s arm—a motion made possible by the surgery performed on that date. State Change’s austere minimalism, generated from electronic tones that subtly build and shift, thus takes on a surprisingly human quality as the record progresses. Its sonic world expands along with Joyce’s abilities throughout the series of surgeries, from the sterile coldness of the opening sine tones to the gentle warmth of the closing synth pads.

“State Change” is painfully honest about Joyce’s experience, but that includes the full spectrum of emotions from shock to hope. What at first seems like a distressing proposition—an album full of graphic depictions of medical trauma—turns cathartic as Joyce’s condition improves. On October 26, 2001, pins were removed from her hand. The song for that date features her left hand operating a pressure sensor that determines the harmonic texture of the chords played by her right, a duet that didn’t seem possible at the album’s start. Over these stately, slow-changing chords, Joyce sings again from her surgeon’s report, which finally shares positive news: “No complications/ Beginning range of motion.”

–Matthew Blackwell","title":"Molly Joyce, “State Leinster"}}],"audio_stream_url":null},{"story_id":185054,"story_date":1751982389,"slug":"various-artists-a-selection-of-music-from-libyan-tapes-habibi-funk-review","description":"A hand-curated selection of cuts that span not only reggae, but funk and disco as well.","full_text":"The desert can be a harsh place to live, but it seems quite hospitable to music. North African artists have spent the better part of two decades proving that the blues, a genre born in the fertile depths of the Mississippi Delta, can thrive in the otherwise unforgiving sands of the Sahara. Now, the prodigious folks at Habibi Funk Records are reminding the world that these artists have been adapting outside genres to their local climes since at least the ‘80s. The label’s latest compilation album features a selection of cassette releases that showcase Libyan interpretations of funk, disco, and especially reggae—another genre that grew up in a very different climate, but found fertile ground on Libya’s sun-drenched Mediterranean shore.

The label is upfront that this album isn’t a collection of hits—and the compilation is the better for it. There’s an eclecticism to the curation that makes it feel like what it is: An exploratory journey through the physical memorabilia of Libya’s music scene from the late ‘80s to the early ‘00s, where every reel offers a chance to turn up a new undiscovered gem. The compilation charts a winding path from the synesthetic synth-pop of “Baed Al Farha” to the soft-edged proto-ambient of “Kul Ghrub” to the brass-forward Pink Floyd interpolation you didn’t realize you needed until Libyan composer Khaled Al Reigh saw fit to breathe it into existence. The tracks are distinct but connected, tied together by a pop-oriented energy that feels universal even as the songs themselves assert a strong sense of place.

Another recurring thread is reggae. Jamaica’s fingerprints are all over the first half of the album, often mixed with other regional or global styles. Cheb Bakr’s “Allom” tempo-twists between head-bobbing reggae and foot-shifting shaabi, while Group Hewaya’s “Irja” teases with a swaggering funk riff before dropping into a laid-back island groove. Elsewhere, the album taps into reggae’s revolutionary roots. A line like “Palestine is my homeland” would likely only be sung metaphorically in Kingston, but it takes on a new significance in the hands of Fathi Aldiyqz and the Sons of Africa Band, speaking to a pan-Arabic struggle against injustice that’s just as tragically necessary today as it was when the song was made.

In reality, though, every track on this album is a form of protest music. Under Gaddafi’s regime, cultural mediums were tightly controlled by the state, which prioritized traditional Libyan styles or anything that could be co-opted for propaganda. Western musical influences were basically outlawed unless adapted to serve the regime’s purposes, meaning this compilation is more than just a collection of good tunes: it’s an anthology of Libyan cultural resistance. Cassette tapes were crucial during this period, allowing artists to distribute their music outside of authoritarian controls. Chronicling that cassette scene, as HFR had done, is a true service to the musical community, providing an account of that scene’s innovation and a testament to its ability to blossom no matter how harsh the conditions.

–Collin Smith","title":"Various Artists, “A Selection Of Music From Libyan Emilia-Romagna"}}],"audio_stream_url":null},{"story_id":184995,"story_date":1751894551,"slug":"sababa-5-nadir-review","description":"A patient record from this instrumental group that asks the same of its listeners.","full_text":"It’s been two years since Paris-based Sababa 5’s previous full-length Aspan, and almost exactly a year since the release of their collaborative EP with Japanese vocalist Yurika Hanashima. And on Nadir, their compositions have a more mature—dare I say sexier—air. It’s possible that the band’s relocation to France has contributed to a slightly more sophisticated version of their sound, which finds its co-ordinates somewhere between Middle Eastern rock, psychedelic funk, and Americana—maybe even some subtle moments of reggae if you lean into the upstrokes, as they do on the gently-meandering “Atom.” To put it another way: If 2022’s self-titled album was a buoyant, jaunty teenager, then “Nadir” is the streetwise, stud-ish twenty-something with a cigarette dangling from their lip. It’s broodier than what the band has offered us before.

Guitarist Ilan Smilan delivers spacious yet earworm-y melodies throughout, layered with fluid wah-wahs—a prime example of his layering can be found on penultimate track “Timor.” He’s in no rush. “Tell,” which evokes traditional Turkish ballads, acts as a centerpiece for the record with a synth line that has an air of bittersweetness. The title track gives its central groove the room to breathe, and the short but compelling “Ignition” blooms outwards in a drone, a tantalizing pre-cursor to evening-bopper “Sab.” The overriding atmosphere of the record is dark, seductive, and quietly cinematic. With “Nadir”, Sababa 5 offer up a record that takes its time, asking us to do the same.

–Tina Edwards","title":"Sababa 5,
